stem: A trauma client has received 12 units of packed red blood cells (PRBCs) in the last hour under the Massive Transfusion Protocol (MTP). He begins to experience muscle tremors and a prolonged QT interval on the monitor. Based on the documentation in the Massive Transfusion & Citrate Monitoring Log tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute neuromuscular irritability during heavy transfusion.
Background: Massive internal hemorrhage from MVC. 12 units PRBCs and 4 units FFP infused.
Assessment: Client has positive Chvostek's sign. EKG shows QT of 0.52 seconds.
Recommendation: Immediate calcium replacement.

tabs.title: MTP Monitoring Log
tabs.content:

Serum Potassium5.1 mEq/LHigh-Normal

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 102/64, HR 118, RR 20. EKG shows T-wave changes and long QT.

actionOptions.text: Administer IV Calcium Gluconate (Antidote for Citrate)
Use a rapid blood warmer for all subsequent units
Administer Magnesium Sulfate to prevent seizures
Stop the transfusion immediately and return the blood to the bank

parameterOptions.text: Ionized Calcium levels and EKG (QT interval)
Presence of Trousseau’s or Chvostek’s signs
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose
Presence of a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: This is MTP-Induced Citrate Toxicity (c2). Blood products are stored with Citrate (an anticoagulant) which binds/chelates the patient's Ionized Calcium. During massive transfusions (>10 units), the liver cannot clear the citrate fast enough, leading to severe hypocalcemia. Hallmark signs: Long QT, tremors, and Chvostek's sign. Priority actions include replacing calcium (a1) and warming the blood (a2) (to help the liver metabolize the citrate). Parameters focus on calcium levels (p1) and neuromuscular signs (p2).
clinicalPearls: For every 3-4 units of blood in an MTP, the physician should be ordering a dose of Calcium.
Ionized Calcium is the 'physiologically active' calcium that matters most in critical care.
Citrate is metabolized by the liver; hypothermic or liver-failure patients are at much higher risk for this toxicity.

questionTrap.trap: Stopping the life-saving MTP because the patient is shaking.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Do not stop the blood; the patient is bleeding to death! Just fix the calcium deficit while the MTP continues.

mnemonic.title: C-C-C
mnemonic.expansion: C-Citrate is the C-Chelator that kills C-Calcium.
